request_pathways.name: Authorization for Release of Health Information
Fax to Northwest locations HIM (Long Prairie)
Mail to Sauk Centre HIM office (serves Long Prairie)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a system-wide generic HIPAA authorization form, prints and completes it by hand, then submits via email, fax, or mail to the regional HIM office.

red_flags: Anti-re-release clause is embedded as non-optional boilerplate — patients cannot choose whether to authorize re-release
No fee information disclosed on form or instructions despite referencing potential costs
bright_spots: Email submission (CCHROI@CentraCare.com) prominently featured and available for all locations
Multiple delivery options including MyChart portal and encrypted email
Personal Use explicitly listed as a reason for release, normalizing patient self-requests
Companion instruction document explains why each field matters, not just what to fill in
Anti-conditioning statement: CentraCare will not refuse treatment for declining to sign

findability.rationale: Level 4: Forms are easy to find via CentraCare's centralized medical records release page and web search, though patients must recognize Long Prairie uses system-wide forms rather than facility-specific ones.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: The form has a text layer but zero fillable fields, requiring print-and-handwrite; however, fax and email submission are available, making it usable digitally with workarounds.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized 2-page form with logical flow, clear section headers, and a comprehensive companion instruction document; minor issues include dense revocation language and the unintuitive From/To structure for self-access.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it was designed for third-party release — the From/To structure requires patients to figure out they should list themselves as the recipient, with no dedicated patient access pathway or HIPAA Right of Access reference.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: No unnecessary barriers (email/fax/mail submission, no notarization), includes anti-conditioning statement; minor gaps include absent fee disclosure and non-optional anti-re-release clause.

overall.summary: CentraCare provides a functional records request process with strong electronic submission and delivery options, but the generic third-party authorization form and non-fillable PDF prevent it from being truly patient-centered.
